questions.text: Which of the following statements about exanthema subitum is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with Slapped Cheek Appearance

 

Explanation:

  • Exanthema subitum, also called Sixth Disease or Roseola infantum, is caused by Human Herpes Virus-6 (HHV-6). 
  • The disease is characterized by abrupt onset of high-grade fever, followed by appearance of the rash after the fever subsides. 
  • The rash resembles measles but is not described as having a "slapped cheek appearance." Nagayama spots are associated with this condition, but not a slapped cheek appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Known as Sixth Disease - This is correct. 

 

  • Exanthema subitum is indeed known as the Sixth Disease in the classification of childhood exanthems.

 

Option B. Known as Roseola - This is correct. 

 

  • HHV-6 causes "roseola infantum" where "roseola" means rose-like and "infantum" refers to its common occurrence in infants.

 

Option C. Caused by Herpes Virus - This is correct. 

 

  • Exanthema subitum is caused by Human Herpes Virus-6 (HHV-6), which is a member of the herpesvirus family.

 

Option D. Associated with Slapped Cheek Appearance - This is incorrect. 

 

  • The "slapped cheek appearance" is characteristic of Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) caused by Parvovirus B19, not exanthema subitum. 

 

 

  • Parvovirus B19 infection causes a maculopapular rash that evolves into a reticulated lacy exanthem

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Exanthema subitum (Sixth Disease/Roseola infantum) is caused by HHV-6, characterized by abrupt high fever followed by a rash after fever subsides, while the "slapped cheek appearance" is characteristic of Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) caused by Parvovirus B19.

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

 

The identification of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as the causative agent in this case of tinea capitis is confirmed by the positive hair perforation test. This test is particularly valuable for differentiating between species of Trichophyton, as it assesses the fungus's ability to penetrate and degrade hair keratin.

 

  • Hair Perforation Test: This diagnostic tool is used to differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from Trichophyton rubrum, as T. mentagrophytes demonstrates the ability to perforate hair, causing surface erosion which gives a wedge-shaped appearance to the hair shaft. This is a key characteristic that helps in identifying the fungal species responsible for the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not typically infect hair, more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Option B. Microsporum audouinii: Causes tinea capitis but does not show a positive result on the hair perforation test.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum: Another cause of tinea capitis but also does not typically show a positive hair perforation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-rebreathing mask

 

  • FiO2 Delivery: A non-rebreathing mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. This mask has a reservoir bag that fills with oxygen and a one-way valve that prevents the exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring a higher concentration of oxygen is inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: The Venturi mask delivers a precise FiO2, which can range from 24% to 66%, depending on the entrainment device used. It is often used in patients who require a specific oxygen concentration.

 

Option B. Hudson mask: This option appears to refer to a simple face mask, which can deliver up to 60% FiO2 at 10 L/min. It is less efficient in delivering high concentrations of oxygen compared to a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Option D. Nasal cannula: A nasal cannula typically delivers up to 44% FiO2 at a flow rate of 6 L/min. It is comfortable and used for patients who need low to moderate oxygen supplementation but cannot deliver the high concentrations achievable with a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask delivers the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy, capable of providing up to 80% FiO2 at flow rates of 10-15 L/min, making it suitable for patients requiring high concentrations of oxygen.

questions.text: Which receptor helps in improvement of insulin resistance in Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus with regular exercise and physical activity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GLUT4

 

GLUT4 is a glucose transporter found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscles (skeletal and cardiac). It is insulin-dependent, meaning its activity increases in response to insulin. During exercise, the translocation of GLUT4 to the cell membrane is stimulated, enhancing glucose uptake into cells even in the absence of insulin. This mechanism is crucial in improving insulin sensitivity and combating insulin resistance, particularly in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2). Regular physical activity enhances this effect, leading to better glucose control and reduction of hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT1: This glucose transporter is found in many tissues, including the brain, and is responsible for basal glucose uptake. It is not significantly influenced by insulin and does not play a direct role in improving insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Option C. GLUT2: GLUT2 is primarily found in the liver, pancreas, kidneys, and intestines. It functions in glucose sensing and plays a role in glucose homeostasis but is not directly involved in the insulin-dependent improvement of glucose uptake seen in DM2.

 

Option D. GLUT3: GLUT3 is a high-affinity glucose transporter found predominantly in neurons. It ensures a constant supply of glucose to the brain, but it is not insulin-dependent and does not have a significant role in the management of insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter that plays a key role in improving insulin resistance with regular exercise and physical activity.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Letulle technique

 

Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

Below image shows Letulle’s Method

 

 

Other Options:

 

Other Autopsy Techniques for Evisceration:

 

Option A. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

Below image shows Virchow’s Method

 

 

Option B. Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

Below image shows Rokitansky Method

 

 

Option C. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

Below image shows Ghon’s Method

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Letulle technique involves removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs en masse, preserving their relationships, and is preferred for infants to observe congenital abnormalities.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, PC dikshit, page 147

choices.text: Paralysis lasting more than 1 to 3 hours

questions.text: In a patient with a normal quantity of pseudocholinesterase and a dibucaine number of 50, what is the likely duration of paralysis following a 1 mg/kg dose of intravenous succinylcholine? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paralysis lasting 20 to 30 minutes

 

A dibucaine number of 50% indicates a heterozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme. While normal individuals (dibucaine number ~80%) metabolize succinylcholine rapidly with paralysis lasting 9-14 minutes, patients with heterozygous atypical enzyme (dibucaine number around 50%) experience intermediate prolongation of neuromuscular blockade. This intermediate enzyme activity results in paralysis lasting approximately 20-30 minutes - longer than normal but not as prolonged as in homozygous atypical cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperkalemic cardiac arrest:  This is a potential complication of succinylcholine in patients with denervation, burns, or muscular dystrophies, but is not directly related to pseudocholinesterase activity or dibucaine number.

 

Option B. Paralysis lasting 5 to 10 minutes: This represents the normal duration of action for succinylcholine in patients with normal pseudocholinesterase activity and normal dibucaine number (~80%). The patient with a Dibucine number of 50% will have a longer duration.

 

Option D. Paralysis lasting more than 1 to 3 hours: This extremely prolonged duration would be seen in homozygous atypical patients with dibucaine numbers around 20%. Since our patient has an intermediate dibucaine number of 50%, the paralysis will be intermediate in duration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A dibucaine number of 50% indicates heterozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase with intermediate enzyme activity, resulting in paralysis lasting 20-30 minutes following succinylcholine administration - longer than normal but not as severely prolonged as in homozygous atypical cases.

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

questions.text: Which of the following medications may be safely discontinued with minimal risk of adverse effects before an abdominal surgery? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE Inhibitors/Angiotensin Receptor Blockers

 

ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) should be omitted on the day of surgery. According to pre-anesthetic evaluation guidelines, while most antihypertensive medications are continued, ACE inhibitors and ARBs are specifically recommended to be withheld due to an increased risk of significant intraoperative hypotension when taken on the morning of surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Statins: These should be continued perioperatively to maintain lipid control and vascular protection.

 

Option B. Beta Blockers: These should be continued on the day of surgery. Abrupt discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, tachycardia, and an increased risk of myocardial ischemia.

 

Option D. Steroids: Patients on chronic steroid therapy should continue their regular dose and receive supplemental IV hydrocortisone perioperatively. Discontinuing steroids can lead to adrenal insufficiency and hemodynamic instability during surgical stress.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While most chronic medications are continued perioperatively, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be withheld on the day of surgery to reduce the risk of intraoperative hypotension. In contrast, beta blockers, statins, and steroids should be continued to avoid potential complications.

questions.text: Which drug would be most effective in preventing withdrawal symptoms in a patient with a history of alcohol consumption who was admitted to the hospital after a road traffic accident? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like anxiety, tremors, seizures, and delirium tremens, which can be life-threatening. Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, work by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the nervous system, thereby reducing the risk of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This drug is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, not for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reduce cravings and prevent relapse in patients recovering from alcohol or opioid dependence. It is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used for the management of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It is not effective for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the drugs of choice to prevent and manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linea semilunaris

 

Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

 

The linea semilunaris is a curved tendinous line located on either side of the rectus abdominis muscle, representing the lateral border where the flat abdominal muscles' aponeuroses come together.

 

It is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique alone. Instead, it is formed where the aponeurosis of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis meet and fuse before they envelop the rectus abdominis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal Ligament: Also known as Cooper's ligament, the pectineal ligament is a fibrous band that runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament, extending from the pubic tubercle to the pectineal line of the pubis. While it is closely related to structures formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique, it is not directly derived from it.

 

Option B. Inguinal Ligament: The inguinal ligament is directly derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. It is the inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis, stretching between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle. This ligament acts as a boundary between the anterior abdominal wall and the thigh, and structures like the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females pass beneath it to enter the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. Lacunar Ligament: Also called Gimbernat’s ligament, the lacunar ligament is a crescent-shaped fold of the aponeurosis of the external oblique that attaches to the pectineal line of the pubis. It's positioned medial to the inguinal ligament, and its formation is related to the deepening of the inguinal canal during development. It contributes to the posterior margin of the superficial inguinal ring and represents the lateral border of the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligaments derived from external oblique aponeurosis are:

questions.text: What type of joint is demonstrated in the highlighted region of the vertebral articulation shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synovial

 

The joint marked in the above image is a synovial joint called the costotransverse and costovertebral joint.

 

These are the most common type of joints in the body. The articulating ends of the bones in these joints are covered with articular cartilage. These bones are enclosed within an articular capsule which has an outer fibrous layer (giving it strength) and an inner synovial membrane which secretes synovial fluid (providing lubrication and nutrients to the joint). Examples include the knee joint, elbow joint, and many others.

 

They are diarthrotic, meaning they are freely movable. The exact range of movement and type of movement (e.g., hinge, pivot, ball-and-socket) varies depending on the specific joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a type of fibrous joint where the bones are joined by a ligament or a membrane. The most commonly referred syndesmosis is the one between the tibia and fibula in the leg, held together by the interosseous membrane and the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments.

 

  • It allows for a slight movement (making it amphiarthrotic), particularly when the foot is dorsiflexed or plantarflexed.

 

Option B. Synarthrosis: This term describes a joint that allows very minimal or no movement. It encompasses several types of joints including sutures (between skull bones), gomphoses (between a tooth and its socket), and synchondroses (which we'll discuss next).

 

  • These are largely immovable joints. They serve to provide stability in certain areas of the body, like the skull, where movement is not desired.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: This is a subtype of synarthrosis, and it's a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined together by hyaline cartilage. A classic example is the joint between the first rib and the sternum, or the epiphyseal plates in growing bones.

 

  • They are immovable (synarthrotic). The primary purpose of these joints is to allow growth of the bone while providing stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Description of the joint present in the thoracic region are as follows:

questions.text: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus anthracis

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis.

 

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

 

  • ﻿﻿Cutaneous Anthrax (hide porter's disease)- Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • ﻿﻿Pulmonary Anthrax (Wool sorter's disease) - Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • ﻿﻿Intestinal Anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhoea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in wounds and burns, often producing a greenish pus but not typically associated with black eschars.

 

Option B. Yersinia pestis: Causes bubonic plague, associated with swollen and painful lymph nodes (buboes) rather than black eschars.

 

Option D. Francisella tularensis: Causes tularemia, which can present with ulcers at the infection site but lacks the characteristic black eschar of anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous anthrax is characterized by the initial appearance of a small pimple that quickly turns into a painless ulcer with a necrotic (black) eschar at the center. This presentation is typical for individuals who have been in contact with infected animals or animal products, which is common in the veterinary profession.

 

Additional Information

 

Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. Hence, he is Known as the Father of Bacteriology.

 

Koch's postulates, which link specific microorganisms to specific diseases, state that the microorganism must be:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent

questions.text: Which tongue papillae do not have taste buds? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Filiform

 

The filiform papillae are the most numerous of the lingual papillae on the tongue, but they do not contain taste buds. They are primarily responsible for the general sensations of touch, temperature, pressure, and texture. Unlike other types of papillae—such as foliate, fungiform, and circumvallate—filiform papillae are not involved in the sensation of taste, which is a special sensory function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foliate: These papillae are located on the lateral sides of the tongue and contain taste buds. They are primarily involved in sensing sweet and sour tastes.

 

Option C. Fungiform Papilla: These are found on the top of the tongue and are involved in sensing sweet, sour, and salty tastes. They contain taste buds.

 

Option D. Circumvallate: These are located at the back of the tongue and are primarily involved in sensing bitter tastes. They also contain taste buds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds and are primarily involved in general sensations like touch and texture, not in the sensation of taste

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

 

The image shows multiple wounds on the hand, indicative of defense wounds. These are injuries received by a victim of an attack while trying to defend against the assailant.

 

Defense wounds are typically found on the hands and forearms, showing deep incised or blunt force injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antemortem wound: Wounds inflicted before death, characterized by bleeding, clot formation, and tissue reaction. Defense wounds are a type of antemortem wound, but the specific context here is self-defense.

 

Option C. Postmortem wound: Wounds inflicted after death, characterized by the absence of vital reactions such as bleeding and clotting.

 

Option D. Hesitation cuts: Multiple, small, superficial incised wounds made by a person during a suicide attempt while hesitating to make a final decisive cut.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A colonoscopy on an 80-year-old patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions, as shown below. He admitted to using laxatives on a regular basis. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to be the source of this problem? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Senna

 

The given image shows the colonoscopy finding of melanosis coli.

 

The use of stimulant purgatives like Senna , Cascara Sagrada and Bisacodyl can lead to the development of melanosis coli. Also they should not be used for more than 10 days due to the risk of developing atonic colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bran: Bran is a bulk-forming laxative that increases stool bulk and promotes regular bowel movements. It does not cause melanosis coli.

 

Option B. Psyllium: Psyllium is another bulk-forming laxative that absorbs water into the stool, making it easier to pass. It does not lead to melanosis coli.

 

Option D. Methylcellulose: Methylcellulose is a bulk-forming fiber laxative that works by absorbing water and increasing stool bulk. It is not associated with melanosis coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic use of stimulant laxatives like Senna can lead to melanosis coli, characterized by brownish-black pigmentation of the colonic mucosa seen on colonoscopy.

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery would most likely compromise the blood supply to which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e., right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

 

 

  • The common hepatic artery typically divides into the hepatic proper artery and the gastroduodenal artery.
  • The hepatic proper artery, in turn, gives rise to the right gastric artery (which supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach) and continues as the left and right hepatic arteries for the liver.
  • The gastroduodenal artery gives off the right gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Thus, if the common hepatic artery is ligated, blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries would be impaired.

 

Branches of hepatic artery (Mnemonic – Girls R So Cute)

 

  • Gastroduodenal artery > divides into right gastroepiploic and superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
  • Right gastric artery
  • Supra duodenal artery (inconstant)
  • Cystic artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right gastric and left gastric artery: While the right gastric artery does arise from the hepatic proper artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery), the left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the left gastric artery's blood supply.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery). The short gastric arteries, however, typically arise from the splenic artery, another direct branch of the celiac trunk. Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the blood supply of the short gastric vessels.

 

Option D. Right gastric and short gastric vessels: As mentioned earlier, the right gastric artery arises from the hepatic proper artery. The short gastric arteries arise from the splenic artery. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would only affect the right gastric artery's blood supply, not the short gastric vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery affects the blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries due to their derivation from the hepatic proper and gastroduodenal arteries respectively.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

 

Explanation

 

The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.

 

 

The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

 

These are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.

 

Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:

 

  1. Fine touch
  2. Tactile localization
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Vibration

 

This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.

 

function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.

 

Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.

 

Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.

 

Additional Information

 

Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)

 

  • I/L loss of Fine touch
  • C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • I/L loss of Proprioception
  • I/L motor paralysis

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

 

Explanation:

 

Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.

 

Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.

 

Option C: Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.

 

Option D: Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior: The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B. Posterior: The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle lobe or median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae." It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula. This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incised looking lacerated wound

 

The image shows a lacerated wound which looks like incised wound. This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”. They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

They can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laceration: Irregular tear-like wounds caused by blunt trauma. They often have jagged edges and may have tissue bridges at the base. The wound in the image appears cleaner and more linear, resembling an incised wound, making it an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Clean, straight cuts typically caused by sharp instruments such as knives or glass. The wound in the image is caused by blunt force and has characteristics of a laceration, despite its appearance.

 

Option C. Lacerated looking incised wound:  In areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc, the shapes are zigzag type. So, although it is produced by sharp weapon but it looks like lacerated wound. Such wounds are sometimes called as lacerated looking incised wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An incised looking lacerated wound is caused by blunt force trauma but appears similar to an incised wound due to its location and the characteristics of the tissue involved.

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter of the skull is smallest in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Brachycephaly

 

Explanation:

 

Brachycephaly (short-headed) is characterized by a skull that has a short anteroposterior diameter compared to its width. This is reflected in the cephalic index formula:

Cephalic Index = (Maximum transverse breadth of skull / Maximum anteroposterior length of skull) × 100

 

Brachycephalic skulls have a cephalic index of 80-85 and are found in Mongoloids. This high index value indicates that the width is large relative to a shorter anteroposterior length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dolichocephaly (Incorrect) Dolichocephalic (long-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 70-75. This indicates a longer anteroposterior diameter relative to width, not shorter.

 

Option B. Mesocephaly (Incorrect) Mesaticephalic (medium-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 75-80. This represents an intermediate anteroposterior diameter.

 

Option D. Trigonocephaly (Incorrect) Trigonocephaly refers to a condition where the skull has a triangular appearance when viewed from above due to premature fusion of the metopic suture. It's not directly classified in the cephalic index system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cephalic index measures the ratio between skull width and length - the higher the index (as in brachycephaly), the shorter the anteroposterior diameter relative to width.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

choices.text: Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness
Activates locus coeruleus and cause wakefulness
No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep
Activates histamine release and prevents sleep

questions.text: A man habitually consumes coffee before bedtime and claims difficulty in sleep during night. What is the role of caffeine in wakefulness? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness

 

Caffeine is a stimulant that is commonly consumed to reduce fatigue and increase alertness. Its primary mechanism of action in promoting wakefulness is through blocking the action of adenosine, a neurotransmitter in the brain that promotes sleep and relaxation by binding to adenosine receptors. Normally, when adenosine binds to its receptors, it leads to drowsiness and a decrease in nerve cell activity. Caffeine, due to its structural similarity to adenosine, competes for these receptors but does not activate them. Instead, it blocks the action of adenosine, preventing the onset of sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness: The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in physiological responses to stress and panic, and it is active during REM sleep to help regulate wakefulness. However, caffeine does not directly activate the locus coeruleus to cause wakefulness; instead, its wakefulness-promoting effect is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade.

 

Option C. No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep: This statement is incorrect because caffeine does play a significant role in maintaining wakefulness even if consumed an hour before sleep. Caffeine has a half-life of about 5-6 hours, meaning it remains active in the system for several hours after consumption, potentially leading to difficulty falling asleep.

 

Option D. Activates histamine release and prevents sleep: Histamine is a neurotransmitter involved in wakefulness, but caffeine does not exert its wakefulness-promoting effects through histamine release. The primary mechanism is through blocking adenosine receptors, not activating histamine release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily by blocking adenosine receptors in the brain, thereby preventing the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine.

questions.text: The ossification center of the clavicle used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Sternal end

 

Explanation:

 

The sternal (medial) end of the clavicle is the ossification center used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage. This is a critical ossification center for age estimation in the late teens and early twenties. The secondary center at the medial end of the clavicle appears at around 18 years of age and fuses with the shaft by 21-22 years of age in males (slightly earlier in females).

 

In the context of legal consent to marriage, which typically requires individuals to be at least 18 years for females and 21 years for males in many jurisdictions, the fusion status of the medial end of the clavicle provides valuable evidence for age determination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromial end (Incorrect) The acromial (lateral) end of the clavicle is not commonly used for age determination related to legal consent for marriage as it fuses earlier and doesn't provide relevant age information for the late teens to early twenties.

 

Option C. Shaft (Incorrect) The shaft (body) of the clavicle is the primary ossification center that appears very early (around 5-6 weeks of intrauterine life) and is the first bone to begin ossification. It doesn't provide useful information for age estimation in the context of marriage consent.

 

Option D. Tubercle (Incorrect) The tubercle of the clavicle doesn't have a separate ossification center that would be relevant for age determination in the context of legal consent for marriage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial (sternal) end of the clavicle is a key marker for age estimation between 18-22 years, making it highly valuable for legal age determination in marriage consent cases.

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

 

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

 

Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.

 

Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.
